title: 113_hr5703
content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property and identifies the appropriate congressional committees. It also includes findings and a statement of policy. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, as it reflects respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. Instances of cultural property loss, damage, and destruction have occurred due to various factors like political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters in countries like Egypt, Iraq, and Syria. Notable examples include the ransacking of museums in Egypt, looting of the Iraq Museum resulting in the loss of thousands of artifacts, and the shelling of medieval cities in Syria during the civil war. In Iraq and Syria, cultural sites and artifacts have been looted and destroyed by ISIS/ISIL, resulting in the loss of thousands of items including ancient amulets, sculptures, and cylinder seals. The ongoing civil war in Syria has also led to damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites and the shelling of medieval cities. In Mali, terrorist groups like Ansar Dine have destroyed tombs and shrines in ancient cities. In Mali, Al-Qaeda affiliated group Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in the ancient city of Timbuktu, threatening collections of ancient manuscripts. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, leading to global condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, desecrated statues, and demolished mosques and Catholic churches. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature. In China, the Cultural Revolution led to the destruction of antiques and old Beijing. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art and archives, while in India, the 2004 tsunami damaged libraries and UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged cultural properties like libraries, archives, and UNESCO World Heritage Sites in eleven countries. The destruction of these sites represents a loss of humanity's cultural heritage. The United States Armed Forces have played a role in preserving cultural property since President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas in 1943. The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, known as the "Monuments Men," were formed during World War II to secure and return stolen art. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield supports the protection of cultural property in armed conflicts and disasters. The United States Government and cultural heritage organizations work together to protect international cultural property from destruction due to political instability, armed conflict, or disasters. The policy includes preserving cultural property, following international conventions, preventing importation of pillaged cultural property, and enforcing existing laws and regulations. The United States Government collaborates with cultural heritage organizations to safeguard international cultural property from destruction caused by political instability, armed conflict, or disasters. This involves preserving cultural property, adhering to international conventions, and implementing laws to prevent the importation and trafficking of stolen or looted cultural artifacts. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is established under Section 4. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection appointed by the President will coordinate and promote efforts involving multiple Federal agencies, submit annual reports to congressional committees, provide policy recommendations, resolve interagency differences, and collaborate with domestic and international actors. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection appointed by the President will coordinate efforts involving multiple Federal agencies, submit annual reports to congressional committees, resolve interagency differences, and collaborate with domestic and international actors to promote and protect international cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities under the Hague Convention and actions taken to protect cultural property in conflicts involving the US. Additionally, information on USAID's activities to protect international cultural property is required. The United States is involved in protecting international cultural property through various actions and statutes. The Department of Defense and USAID are required to provide information on their efforts to protect cultural property at risk of destruction due to various factors. The Secretary of Defense must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including actions taken to prevent damage during construction activities abroad. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including using statutes and regulations in criminal actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property. The Department of Justice must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including using statutes and regulations in criminal actions to prevent trafficking in stolen cultural property and interdict transnational organized crime. They must also detail actions taken to ensure consistent and effective application of law in cases related to international cultural property located in or attempted to be imported into the United States. Federal agencies can engage in international cultural property protection activities with the Smithsonian Institution. They are authorized to enter agreements to temporarily use Smithsonian personnel for this purpose. Agencies can pay for salaries and expenses to support these activities, including military, diplomatic, and law enforcement efforts. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, there is emergency protection for Syrian cultural property. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological or ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. The restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, and apply to cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The term "Syria" refers to cultural property and other items of archaeological, historical, cultural, scientific, or religious importance unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The term "State Party" is defined in the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
